case_name: Jugalkishore Saraf v. Raw Cotton Company Limited

facts.text: Two persons named Mahomedali Habib and Sakerkhanoo Mahomedali Habib carried on business as merchants and pucca adatias in bullion and companyton at Bombay under the name Habib Sons.

anchor.surface_text: Two persons named Mahomedali Habib and Sakerkhanoo Mahomedali Habib used to carry on business as merchants and pucca adatias in bullion and companyton at Bombay under the name and style of Habib Sons.

facts.text: In 1948, Habib Sons instituted Summary Suit No. 233 of 1948 in Bombay City Civil Court against Jugalkishore Saraf for recovery of Rs. 7,113-7-0 with 6% interest per annum due on transactions in gold and silver.

anchor.surface_text: In 1948 that firm instituted a suit in the Bombay City Civil Court, being Summary Suit No 233 of 1948, against the present appellant Juga-lkishore Saraf, a Hindu inhabitant carrying on business at Bombay, for the recovery of Rs. 7,113-7-0 with interest at 6 per cent. per annum said to be due by him to the firm in respect of certain transactions in gold and silver effected by the firm as pucca adatias.

facts.text: On 7th February 1949, while the summary suit was pending, a document was executed whereby Habib Sons agreed to transfer all book and other debts due in connection with their business in Bombay to Messrs Raw Cotton Company Limited (respondent).

anchor.surface_text: On the 7th February,. 1949 when that summary suit was still pending a document was executed whereby it was agreed that the two partners would transfer and Messrs Raw Cotton Company, Limited,  hereinafter called the respondent companypany  1372 would accept the transfer of, inter alia, all book and other debts due to them in companynection with their business in Bombay and full benefit of all securities for the debts and all other property to which they were entitled in companynection with the said business.

facts.text: Respondent did not take steps under Order XXII rule 10 CPC to substitute as plaintiffs in the suit, allowing it to continue in name of original plaintiffs Habib Sons.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companypany did number take steps under 0. XXII, r. 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure to get themselves substituted as plaintiffs in the place and stead of Habib Sons, the plaintiffs on record, but allowed the suit to be companytinued in the name of the original plaintiffs.

facts.text: The two partners of Habib Sons migrated from India to Pakistan and their properties vested in the Custodian of Evacuee Property.

anchor.surface_text: Evidently, the two partners migrated from India to Pakistan and their properties vested in the Custodian of Evacuee Property.

facts.text: On 15th December 1949, decree passed in summary suit for Rs. 8,018-7-0 principal and interest, Rs. 410 costs, total Rs. 8,428-7-0, plus 4% interest from decree date.

anchor.surface_text: On the 15th December 1949 a decree was passed in the summary suit for the sum of Rs. 8,018-7-0 for the debt and interest and the sum of Rs. 410 for companyts of the suit, aggregating to Rs. 8,428-7-0, and for further interest at 4 per cent. per annum from the date of the decree until payment.

facts.text: Decree passed in favour of Habib Sons as plaintiffs on record.

anchor.surface_text: Habib Sons being the plaintiffs on record the decree was passed in their favour.

facts.text: On 2nd August 1950, Additional Custodian of Evacuee Property confirmed the transfer of business of Habib Sons to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On the 11th December 1950 the Custodian of Evacuee Property, Bombay, informed the respondent companypany that by an order made on the 2nd August 1950 the Additional Custodian of Evacuee Property had companyfirmed the transaction of transfer of the business of Habib Sons to the respondent companypany.

facts.text: On 11th December 1950, Custodian informed respondent of confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: On the 11th December 1950 the Custodian of Evacuee Property, Bombay, informed the respondent companypany that by an order made on the 2nd August 1950 the Additional Custodian of Evacuee Property had companyfirmed the transaction of transfer of the business of Habib Sons to the respondent companypany.

facts.text: On or about 25th April 1951, respondent presented tabular statement for execution under O XXI r 11 CPC, praying for declaration as assignees of decree and substitution.

anchor.surface_text: On or about the 25th April, 1951 the respondent companypany presented before the Bombay City Civil Court a tabular statement purporting to be an application for execution under Order XXI,rule 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure. In the last companyumn of the tabular statement, under the heading The mode in which the assistance of the Court is required, the respondent companypany prayed that the Court be pleased to declare the Applicants the assignees of the decree as the decrement debt along with other debts bad been transferred by the plaintiffs to the Applicants by a deed of assignment dated the 7th February 1949 which was companyfirmed by the Custodian of Evacuee Property, Bombay, and order them to be substituted for the plaintiffs.

facts.text: On 10th May 1951, City Civil Court issued notice under O XXI r 16 to Habib Sons and Jugalkishore Saraf.

anchor.surface_text: On the 10th May 1951 the Bombay City Civil Court issued a numberice under Order XXI, rule 16 of the Code to Habib Sons, who were the decree-holders on record, and Jugalkishore Saraf, who was the defendant judgment-debtor, requiring them to show cause why the decree passed in the suit on the 15th December 1949 in favour of the plaintiffs and by them transferred to the respondent companypany, should number be executed by the said transferees against the said defendant judgment-debtor.

facts.text: Jugalkishore Saraf filed affidavit on 15th June 1951 denying execution of document and that it transferred the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant judgment-debtor showed cause by filing an affidavit affirmed by him on the 15th June 1951. Amongst other things, he denied that the document in question had been executed or that the document transferred the decree to the respondent companypany.

facts.text: Executing Court (City Civil Court) proved execution of document by attesting witness evidence, accepted it, rejected contention on transfer, made notice absolute, allowed respondent to execute with costs. Order dated 20th November 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was tried on evidence and the execution of the document was proved by the evidence of an attesting witness which has been accepted by the executing Court. The executing Court, however, rejected the second companytention and made the numberice absolute with companyts and gave leave to the respondent companypany to execute the decree against the judgment-debtor.

facts.text: Jugalkishore appealed to High Court, Appeal No. 67 of 1952, dismissed by Dixit J on 23rd September 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor filed an appeal before the High Court. The appeal was heard by Dixit, J. ... and affirming the order of the executing Court dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal No. 8 of 1953 before Bombay High Court dismissed by Chagla CJ and Shah J on 10th November 1953, granted certificate under Art 133(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor preferred a Letters Patent Appeal before the High Court which was dismissed by Chagla, J., and Shah, J., following the two earlier decisions mentioned above. They, however,  1  1877 I.L.R. 11 Bom. 506. I.L.R. 1946 Bom. 276. 1374 granted, under article 133  1   c  of the Constitution, a certificate of fitness for appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 212 of 1954 before Supreme Court, heard on 7 March 1955.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 212 of 1954. ... 1955. March 7. The following Judgments were delivered.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that document dated 7 Feb 1949 did not transfer the decree as it was executed before decree passed, no agreement to transfer future decree.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite plain that if .Order XXI, rule 16 is thus companystrued the respondent companypany cannot possibly companytend that the decree number sought to be executed by them was, after its passing, transferred to them by an assignment in writing within the meaning of that rule, for the document in question was executed on the 7th February 1949 but the decree was passed subsequently on the 15th December 1949.

facts.text: Supreme Court held respondent entitled to execute decree under Section 146 CPC as persons claiming under decree-holder, being assignees of the debt.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the respondent companypany are entitled under section 146 to make the application for execution which the original decree- holders companyld do.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that this appeal must be dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: Bhagwati J agreed appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: BHAGWATI J.-I agree that the appeal be dismissed with companyts.

holdings.text: The respondent company cannot claim to be transferees of the decree by assignment in writing under Order XXI rule 16 because the document was executed before the decree was passed.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite plain that if .Order XXI, rule 16 is thus companystrued the respondent companypany cannot possibly companytend that the decree number sought to be executed by them was, after its passing, transferred to them by an assignment in writing within the meaning of that rule, for the document in question was executed on the 7th February 1949 but the decree was passed subsequently on the 15th December 1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal construction of O XXI r 16 requires sequence: decree first, then transfer by assignment in writing; document predates decree.

holdings.text: The document dated 7th February 1949 does not transfer or constitute an agreement to transfer the future decree.

anchor.surface_text: On a true companystruction of the document the transferors agreed only to transfer, besides the five items of specified properties, All other properties to which the vendors are entitled, that is to say, all properties to which at the date of the document they were entitled. At the date of the document they had the right to proceed with the suit and to get such relief as the Court by its decree might award but nodecree had yet been passed in that suit,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document transfers existing entitlements in present tense ('are entitled'); no mention of suit or future decree; TPA s8 passes only then-existing interests.

holdings.text: Equitable assignment of future property does not constitute an 'assignment in writing' under Order XXI rule 16.

anchor.surface_text: the after acquired property cannot, logically and on principle, be said to have been transferred to the intending transferee by the agreement in writing. I do number see on what principle this transfer can be said to relate back to the previous agreement. I am fortified in my view by the observations of Lord Cave in the case of Performing Right Society v. London Theatre of Varie- ties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equity operates dehors prior agreement, treating as done what ought to be done; does not relate back to validate prior document as statutory 'assignment in writing'; distinguished English precedents.

holdings.text: Respondent company did not become transferees of decree by operation of law under Order XXI rule 16.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent companypany cannot, therefore, claim to companye under Order XXI, rule 16 as transferees by operation of law and cannot maintain the application for execution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No agreement to transfer decree, so no equitable operation; 'operation of law' broad (statutory/equitable force), but inapplicable here.

holdings.text: Respondent company entitled to execute decree under section 146 CPC as persons claiming under original decree-holders.

anchor.surface_text: In my opinion, the respondent companypany are entitled under section 146 to make the application for execution which the original decree- holders companyld do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assignees of debt (subject-matter) are real owners of resultant decree; claim under transferors who continued suit as benamidars; O21 r16 no bar.

holdings.text: Execution application under O XXI r 11 not defective as objection not raised below.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the appellant companytends that the application for execution was defective in that although it purported to be an application for execution under Order XXI, rule 1 1, it did number companyply with the requirements of that rule in that it did number specify any of the several modes ... In these circumstances, it is number open to the appellant to companytend that the application is number maintainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defect acknowledged but no objection in lower courts; subsequent compliant application filed; waived.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that this appeal must be dismissed with companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: On above grounds, upholding lower courts' allowance of execution.
